title: Silver Fox phishing campaign targets Indian taxpayers with ValleyRAT malware
executive_summary: The China-linked threat actor Silver Fox has been observed targeting Indian users with income tax-themed phishing emails to distribute a modular remote access trojan called ValleyRAT.
The campaign involves deception, DLL hijacking, persistence mechanisms, and modular payload delivery that supports keylogging, credential theft, and defense evasion.
what_happened: Researchers from CloudSEK reported that Silver Fox sent phishing emails to Indian recipients claiming to be from the Indian Income Tax Department.
The emails contained decoy PDFs that, when opened, redirected victims to a malicious domain that served a ZIP file with a staged malware installer.
The installer used a legitimate executable and a rogue DLL to sideload and evade detection, ultimately deploying ValleyRAT for remote access and further malicious actions.
who_is_affected: Indian taxpayers and individuals receiving finance-related communications
Organizations in India where employees interact with external email communications
Users of Windows systems susceptible to modular RAT deployment
attack_flow: User opens decoy PDF and is redirected to malicious domain
ZIP archive with staged installer is delivered
Installer sideloads malicious DLL and disables protections
ValleyRAT is injected and establishes persistence
business_impact: Compromise of user credentials and system access
Unauthorized remote control of infected Windows hosts
Data theft and potential spread to internal networks
Increased operational risk due to unauthorized remote access
risk_reason: Phishing campaigns that leverage trusted or official themes—such as tax communications—can increase user trust and significantly raise the likelihood of successful infection with persistent malware.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Users open attachments believing them to be legitimate
Defender or Windows Update services are disabled by malware to avoid detection
Malicious installers bypass basic static analysis via DLL hijacking

immediate: Block the malicious domains and email senders at the email gateway
Educate users to verify unexpected tax-related emails before opening attachments
short_term: Implement advanced email filtering with URL and attachment sandboxing
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) to catch hidden persistence mechanisms
long_term: Conduct phishing simulation training for staff
Enforce least-privilege execution policies for Windows hosts
Monitor for abnormal C2 traffic from endpoints

what_this_does_not_mean: All emails about taxes are malicious—only specific phishing campaigns with malware attachments are risky
ValleyRAT automatically spreads to every network without user interaction

signs: Unusual outbound connections to unknown IPs or domains
Unexpected scheduled tasks or registry entries
User report of unexpected downloads after opening tax-related emails
